Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 02:11PM LuvRVing wrote: I have learned That waiting is a bitch! That breast cancer sucks! That there are at least a dozen different types of breast cancer. That treatment options are unique to each person, each instance of BC, and each person's individual other health issues That I hate the term "chemo is doable" because it's not doable for everyone.  And oh, amputations are "doable" too, but no one electively selects to lose a limb.  Yet people sometimes "elect" chemo when the benefit is statistically low and then they end up with long-term side effects because you can't know in advance whether or not you will get through chemo relatively unscathed That even though you think you have done everything in life to be "low risk" you can still be the 1 in 8 that will have BC That the older you are, the higher your risk of getting BC That even if you throw the book at your BC, there is no such thing as "cured" and you run the risk that it can return months, years or decades later That you must appreciate each and every single day of your life because you cannot know what the future holds for you That we need a real, honest-to-goodness "cure"!  I'm talking a cure like, when you have appendicitis, you have the appendix removed, it can't come back.  Too many women die from breast cancer; so yes, we need a real cure! Michelle

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 08:45AM LuvRVing wrote: Trinity - to properly stage your cancer, your doctor needs to know the size of your tumor, the number of nodes that test positive for cancer, and whether or not the cancer has spread to a distant location (bone, liver, etc).  During surgery, the surgeon will probably remove the "sentinel nodes" and those will be tested immediately (during surgery).  If any of the sentinel nodes test positive, the surgeon will likely remove additional nodes.  All this information is sent to the pathologist who will assess everything and then determine the stage based on established criteria. http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis/staging.jsp Everything you are describing sounds very typical. Sometimes, for women with large tumors and where ultrasound or MRI has shown likely involved lymph nodes or for women who want to save as much breast tissue as possible, a preliminary stage is determined and those women usually undergo chemo prior to surgery.  Hugs, Michelle

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 11:16AM LuvRVing wrote: I filed for SSDI while on unemployment (I had taken a separation package several months before being diagnosed).  When I completed the online application, I stated my day of disability as the day I had my BMX after my second DX, but the SSA actually backdated my disability to the day of my first DX.  So I then received a lump sum payment for a year's worth of SSDI last October, and have been receiving monthly payments ever since.  By my calculations, I will have fulfilled the 24 month waiting period to qualify for Medicare this October.  The online application is relatively straightforward.  It's a good idea to have all your medical providers' contact information at your fingertips.  The more you send them yourself, the quicker you will get an answer.  From application to lump sum deposit was about 10 weeks in my case.  I actually got the payment before I received the notice of determination, which made for a very pleasant surprise.

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2010 10:04PM LuvRVing wrote: Hi everyone!  Surgery and SNB is over, I am home and feeling amazingly good.  I am in my recliner and letting DH or DD wait on me. There were absolutely no surprises today, for which I am truly thrilled.  The tumor was the 3 cm that everyone except the fired onco believed to be true.  The SN biopsy was clear and no nodes are involved.  The little spot that had shown up on Monday's MRI was just another hematoma from the core biopsy.  Apparently, the BS considered removing all the hematomas that I have (while I was under) but decided against it because it would have been too much.  She told me that it could take a whole year for those suckers to disappear. I have the place holders for the Mammosite radiation installed so I can't take a shower for a while.  That's a bit of a pain, but a small price to pay for 5 days of rads instead of 33.  Things are looking better each and every day. Worldwatcher - it's hard to be certain about this, but if I were 70, I am pretty sure I would not do chemo.  I'd go for the hormone therapy but have my hormones tested so that you know how much is in your system and how long you really need to take them.  And consider researching "estrogen-reducing" foods.  Ask you oncologist to run the AdjuvantOnline test which should give you an idea of the benefits of chemo for someone your age with your type and grade of cancer.  It takes 2 minutes to enter the data and get an answer.  I have it bookmarked and have run my own (pretending to be a medical professional) so that I really understand the benefits to be gained from chemo.  For me it's only 5% with the data we currently have available.  I'll be sending positive thoughts your way for Friday! Michelle

Enjoy your weekend at the lake, sounds absolutely delightful!  We don't have an RV yet, the plan is to sell the home in two years and go full time for a while.  I can't wait!  Take care! Michelle

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2012 01:02PM - edited Sep 19, 2012 08:47PM by LuvRVing Thanks, Laurie!  I had been watching these threads but didn't think I'd be on the interrogated list this soon!!!  And thanks, English Major, for including me! 1.  My husband and I met in a bowling alley in Pulaski, NY, on the shores of Lake Ontario.  We had both been married before.  He didn't have any children from his first marriage but I was a package deal - I had two boys and a girl when we got married (and "we" had one on the way).  We moved back to my home town of Nashua, NH (he's from Long Beach, CA) and lived there until 1990.  He works for a telecom company and they relocated us to CT.  We lived in Trumbull for 4 years then they moved us again to Blue Springs, MO, near Kansas City.  All of our kids had grown up and moved back to NH/MA so the second breast cancer diagnosis was all it took to make us move back to NH.  Our son found us a little house to rent on a lake here in Salem and we love it here.  We still have our house in MO, but we lease it out and will continue to do so until the market makes selling it feasible. 2.  RVing - nope, we don't own one.  We've rented and borrowed several and we took many trips while we were living in Kansas City.  But the first and longest trip was when we were still in CT.  Our daughter decided to go to college in Oregon (yeah, 3000 miles away) so we packed up her stuff and used every available "luggage allowance" to get her out there, along with our younger daughter, my mom and DH.  We flew into San Francisco and picked up a CruiseAmerica motorhome, then drove up the CA coast, through the Redwoods, up to Crater Lake, then back down to Ashland, OR to her college.  From there we drove down through Nevada over to Yosemite then back up to San Francisco.  From MO, we went to Mount Rushmore, Badlands, Grand Canyon, Bryce Canyon, Zion National Park, Land Between the Lakes, Carlsbad Caverns and a few other places.  When the kids were little, we didn't have a lot of money for vacations, so we bought tents and supplies and we did many a weekend in a state park campground.  Then we graduated to a pop-up and camped at many places in New England including Bar Harbor, ME.  Can you tell we love national parks?  Our "plan" is to retire and do full-time RVing.  But because they are so expensive, we didn't want to buy one until we were ready to jump in with both feet.  We're holding onto this dream - we want to drive through Canada to Alaska and spend several weeks in Denali National Park and whatever else is along the way.  I've never driven an RV - my DH loves, loves, loves to drive and so when we go anywhere, he is the pilot and I am the navigator!  Gas mileage - yeah, pretty sucky.  Maybe 10 mpg if you're lucky if we get a big diesel-pusher.  But we may settle for something smaller, gas-powered and might get that mileage up to 13 or so.  Breast cancer may put a crimp in our style...we'll see.  We're not ready to abandon this particular dream. 3.  What would I want people to know about triple negative BC... I think there's a misconception that it's a "younger" woman's diagnosis or more prevalent in African-Americans.  I've seen so many women like me - 60 or over - who are TNs that I question how accurate those assumptions might be.  And we need more research to develop treatments specific to our sub-type.  I am actually participating in a clinical trial specific to metastatic triple negative breast cancer.  I feel like a pioneer as there aren't that many trials that are specific to us.   I hope that others will consider a trial, whether it's a new drug, a vaccine, or whatever else might come along that looks promising. 4. Who would play me in a movie of my life? My daughter told me I looked like Sara Palin when I was younger, so I'll go with Tina Fey.  Besides, it needs to be someone with a great sense of humor!  And my DH said John Goodman would play him...lol!  Now, that would be quite a pair! One of my sons would be played by Michael Richards (from Seinfeld and SNL) - he used to blow things up and do all kind of crazy things that young teenagers do.  My daughter with the 3 kids would be played by Kristen Wiig - incredible sense of humor. The youngest daughter would be played by Mayim Bialik (Blossom and Big Bang Theory) - she's really smart.  And my oldest son would be played by John Stossel - he's a libertarian all the way.   Yeah, I think sometimes our family is like a Saturday Night Live skit!!!  5. Have I ever met anyone famous? Not really, just MO Senator Claire McCaskill in a restaurant in Kansas City.  And Tom Watson (the golfer) at a theater in Kansas City  I'd love to meet Ellen Degeneres or Michelle Obama. I love Ellen's show and all the wonderful things she does for people in need, adopting a school, for acknowledging and rewarding people who do amazing things. And I love Michelle Obama's programs to get kids moving and eating healthier. Thanks again for including me! It's getting past my bedtime so I need to think about who's next. I'll get my act together and post in the morning.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 10:32AM LuvRVing wrote: I am 60, had a 1.8 cm IDC, grade 3, barely ER+, no nodes or vascular involvement, with a high oncotype score (50). I decided against chemo because I am also diabetic and my research indicated that diabetics do not tolerate chemo as well as non-diabetics.  I spoke with three oncologists who all wanted me to do chemo.  I asked about the diabetes factor and they all said "diabetics do fine with chemo."   However, published studies in their own research publications (Journal of Clinical Oncology) indicate the opposite.  One oncologist actually suggested that MD Anderson's study of the impact of diabetes on breast cancer outcomes was "irresponsible."  Seriously???  These doctors were either dishonest or uninformed within their own specialty.  I didn't need to be a statistician to understand the situation and make a decision that was right for me.  I just needed to be able to read and comprehend. I opted for a lumpectomy, Mammosite radiation and Femara.  I have a friend who has had breast cancer three times.  The first time she had lumpectomy and radiation.  Two years later she had a recurrence and had a mastectomy and AC.  That was twelve years ago.  She was trying to get me to "throw the book at breast cancer so it wouldn't come back."  Then, within weeks of my diagnosis, she was diagnosed with a new cancer in her other breast and had a second mastectomy.   This time she opted for no chemo, no anti-hormones, no follow-up at all. There is no way to know if chemo will keep you safe from cancer in the future.  If an oncologist uses the word "cure" or "insurance" you should be suspicious.   Do your own research and make your own decision.  Most importantly, understand the potential side effects and decide if you can live with them, should you be the "one" who ends up with heart damage, permanent neuropathy, permanent hair loss, chemo brain, leukemia or whatever else could happen while you try to kill off the cells that "may or may not" be lurking in your body.   Looking at this side of a chemo decision is just as important as considering how you would feel if you passed on chemo and you had a recurrence. Michelle

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 09:24AM LuvRVing wrote: DM13 - sorry you are facing this dilemma!  I can't even count how many surgeries I've had in the last 18 months thanks to the gift that keeps on giving!  I can say that the port insertion surgery was one of the easiest, and my surgeon removed it in her office so it was not another surgery.  The test you are asking about is the Oncotype test.  It is expensive, but your insurance will probably cover it.  It will look at the genetics of your tumor and estimate your risk of distant recurrence, which will then provide some guidance as to whether or not you truly need chemo.    It takes a couple weeks for the results but it is worth the wait.  In many cases, chemo is not much of a benefit for those who have small tumors with no nodes involved.  The five years of hormone therapy may be adequate.  You might also consider getting a second opinion from another MO in a different practice than your current MO's. You are in LA - perhaps you can go to one of the big cancer centers in the area. You are not being a big baby - this all sucks big time and we all freak out at the point where we are still trying to figure out the best course of treatment. Hugs, Michelle

Posts.Content: LuvRVing wrote: I had my first post-lumpectomy mammogram and ultrasound today, which took a really long time.  As usual, waiting for results are stressful.  And the last thing I wanted to hear was "the radiologist would like to review the results with you."  The ultrasound showed 3 or 4 small "nodules" close to the skin surface, at least one of them with vascular involvement.  And she recommended doing a biopsy.  We then discussed my previous biopsy and the huge hematomas that resulted.  And I told her that the surgeon had intended to remove them during my lumpectomy but decided against it because she saw they were being fed by arteries.  According to the surgeon, it will take a year for them to be reabsorbed.  So, with that knowledge, I said no to a biopsy and agreed that we will do another ultrasound in March just before my next followup with my breast surgeon.  I was mentally prepared for those hematomas to show up and cause concern.  I'm glad I was aware of what was going on so that I could actually reassure the radiologist that we could take a "wait and see" approach.  As long as they don't get bigger, there's no reason to think there's any trouble brewing.  Everything else looked good.  Glad that's out of the way for three months! Michelle Michelle - read my blog at www.mch-breastcancer.blogspot.com - Be kind to one another! Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 04:37PM LuvRVing wrote: Formygirls - I have been diabetic since 2001, long before I had breast cancer.  And I always kept my blood sugar in good control to avoid complications, eye problems, kidney failure, etc.  Now here I am, just recently diagnosed with mets, and I am torn as to how "loose" I want to be with my diet.  My oncologist suggested that keeping glucose levels in check was still important.  So you can see there are varying opinions...what a surprise...LOL! Cynthia gave you some good ideas on how to add protein to your diet...nuts, peanut butter, cottage cheese, no sugar Greek yogurt (add splenda and berries for a great breakfast), etc.  Will you eat fish or seafood?  Generally speaking fruit smoothies are a carbfest, not something I would do.  You'd really be better off eating the fruit and adding some protein with it (like the yogurt or cottage cheese).  One of my favorite snacks is slices of Granny Smith apples with peanut butter or a really good sharp cheddar cheese.  It's interesting that this topic would come up today.  I was interviewed this afternoon by the science editor of Diabetes Forecast who was doing a story on diabetes and cancer.  She was particularly interested in how I kept my glucose in control while doing chemo.  One thing that was a big issue for me was the Decadron.  I was well aware that steroids would cause problems.  My oncologist reduced my Decadron dose to just 6 mg on treatment day.  None before, none after.  That worked really well. But I see you have brain mets so a dose reduction may not be possible for you. I ate small, frequent meals which helped.  I actually lost about 6 pounds by the time I finished DD AC/T last fall.  And I did eat ice cream at least a couple times a week.  A kiddie size, but still - real ice cream.  And I've loosened up a lot with desserts, pasta, etc.  Life is too short to not eat cake or a yummy blueberry muffin. All that said, I would be concerned by readings in the 200's.  High glucose can affect your vision in the short term, and I wouldn't want to deal with that complication.  Because I've been diabetic for so long, I don't want to test the theory that I might not be around long enough for complications to set in.  Right now, I feel perfectly fine and I've even started to ride a bike 6 miles at a time, 3 or 4 times a week.  Everyone's situation is unique - I hope you can find a "happy medium" that works for you. Hugs, Michelle

Posts.Content: LuvRVing wrote: I don't post on this particular forum very often, but I wanted to spread some happiness.  I had a PET/CT scan yesterday and I got the call this morning - NED!!!!!!!!!   I was first diagnosed in June 2010 with a Stage 1, clear sentinel nodes, 1.7 cm tumor.  I was slightly ER+ and I didn't do chemo.  I had a lumpectomy in mid-July followed by Mammosite radiation, then went on Femara.  In March of this year, I was diagnosed with a recurrence (or leftover cancer, more likely) in the area of the biopsy hematomas near my lumpectomy scar.  I had developed a large seroma in that area and a biopsy showed a 4.6 cm lesion.  A PET showed extension to the skin, 3 axillary nodes and 3 or 4 internal mammary nodes.  I had a BMX with TE's in April along with full axillary dissection.  Nothing could be done at the time about the internal mammary nodes.  The oncologist said that they would be used to tell if chemo was working. I did DD AC/T starting June 15th and finished on 9/28. I'm no spring chicken at 61 and I am diabetic, but I tolerated chemo a whole lot better than anyone, including myself, expected. And now, I am cancer-free! I am meeting with the head of Radiation Oncology at Dana Farber on Friday. I have a complicated radiation situation because I already had Mammosite just last year. And I have underfilled tissue expanders (in anticipation of DIEP reconstruction rather than implants).   So I will have one of the best minds in the country to help figure this out. I am living proof that there is hope and that all the crap we go through can pay off.  I have decided that 9/28/2011 will be my "cancerversary."  There are lots of ideas about what date to use; for me, the day I finished chemo is the day I became cancer-free.  And that is a day to track and celebrate! Michelle Michelle - read my blog at www.mch-breastcancer.blogspot.com - Be kind to one another! I'm going to Dana Farber on Friday and hopefully, we'll agree to a plan.  My preference is to go with http://www.dana-farber.org/research/clinical-trials/clinical-trial.aspx?tid=2410 assuming I qualify.  I think it would be helpful for us to keep this thread going with any clinical trials that we are on or have been on, and how it went for us.  Thank you all for sharing your knowledge! Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 10:04PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:17AM by LuvRVing I am a 10 year diabetic who was diagnosed with breast cancer this summer.  I can attest to the fact that neither is fun.  I understand that those of us with breast cancer can get sick of Pink October. And I suspect that some with diabetes feel that not enough media/marketing attention is paid to that disease by comparison.  Even though there is a diabetic "explosion" with estimates that by the year 2050 one third of all people will have type 2 diabetes, there is not at the moment a single research effort I could find that is addressing the effects of chemotherapy on diabetics under the age of 65.  Not one.  I asked the Komen Foundation.  Even though my BC is "almost" triple negative (ER is 8%, PR is 3%) and my oncotype score was 50, I passed on chemo because I feared the neuropathy and the effects of steroids on my diabetes from a long term perspective more than I feared the possibility of a recurrence.  I could find no study that reassured me that I wouldn't end up with permanent side effects from chemo with no proof that I either had a rogue cancer cell that got past the sentinel nodes or that chemo would eliminate the chance of recurrence.  And three oncologists could offer nothing because there's no research underway.  The only clinical studies were done on information from the Medicare database so all the information was for women 65 and over, and the data analyzed by MD Anderson demonstrated that diabetics do not tolerate chemo well, end up with more severe side effects that require hospitalization, and are more likely to suffer long-term neuropathy.   I am 60 so I had to pay attention to that information as it was the best available data.  I suspect the comment is nothing more than a plea for attention to another killer disease and whoever wrote the original comments was envious of the attention being given to breast cancer.   The ADA needs to hire the Komen marketeers! Michelle

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 12:31PM LuvRVing wrote: People generally get "about" the same cumulative dosage of radiation during the course of their treatments.  How that dosage is divided up into doses or "fractions" is usually very customized.  And it's quite dependent upon the skill of the RO and the radiation equipment he has available to him.  My first RO was going to give me 25 treatments and 5 boosts but told me about the significant risk of heart and lung damage.  Then I consulted with the Chair of RO at Dana Farber.  He was able to develop a radiation protocol unique to me and my anatomy, and avoid heart and lung damage.  I had 11 different-length zaps because of all the different angles he used to radiate my chest wall, supra-clavicle and mammary nodes while avoiding my vital organs. If you think of it as "everyone who gets a lumpectomy automatically must have radiation" then yes, there is a "standard of care" or one-size fits all approach.  But when you dig deeper, you find out the intricacies that are specific to your own situation.  And there are some cancers that are so tiny that even radiation after lumpectomy "may" be over-kill.  Statistically, rads after lumpectomy lowers risk of recurrence.  But that doesn't mean that there aren't people who can safely skip it.  That's where an in-depth discussion with your RO is in order. By the way, my "recurrence" was in the area of my Mammotome biopsy scar, which obviously was not removed during my lumpectomy.  Gotta wonder about that.

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2012 09:34AM LuvRVing wrote: When I was on IV chemo and for every surgical procedure, I've had a scopolamine patch.  It's what they use for motion sickness.  For me, it has worked beautifully.  The one downside - it makes me thirsty.  The upside of that - it ensures I get proper hydration.  I applied the patch the morning of chemo and then wore it for about four days after treatment.  And, are you getting Emend?  It's a miracle drug.  I took one pill as a pre-med, then one for each of the next two days.  It stays in your system for several days.  I didn't experience any SEs from it.  My other pre-med was IV aloxi.  It's similar to zofran and I never had any constipation issues.  Be sure to drink plenty of fluids - 96 ounces a day between your liquids, fruit, soups, puddings, etc.  I lived on watermelon while doing DD AC/T and it really helped me.  Grapes, melons, citrus - anything "juicy" should help. I hope you can come up with a combo that gives you relief.  Nausea and dizziness suck. Hugs, Michelle
